SENT.plain: A family study was carried out to clarify the problem of two separate muscle disease phenotypes in a large consanguineous pedigree
These were a severe limb-girdle type muscular dystrophy and a mild late onset distal myopathy
Thirty-two first degree and 14 other relatives of 18 previously examined index patients were available for clinical examination
Twenty-three subjects underwent computed tomography of the lower leg muscles
No new cases of limb-girdle type muscular dystrophy were found
Distal myopathy was diagnosed in 14 subjects, 10 first degree relatives and four other relatives
Segregation analysis showed that the corrected proportion of affected with the severe proximal type was 0.246 and the proportion of affected with the distal myopathy was 0.58
Pedigree analysis is compatible with the possibility that the mild, late onset distal myopathy is caused by a dominant gene and that the limb-girdle type may be expressed in homozygotes
